entries.title: Two-layer spacing system: precision (4pt) + rhythm (8pt)
entries.description: One scale, two layers. Modern design systems don't choose between 4pt or 8pt — they assign responsibility.
entries.example: Precision: Icons, typography baselines, and internal component spacing. Rhythm: Layout spacing, padding, margins, and component sizing

entries.title: Spacing token: micro (4px)
entries.description: Use: Icon ↔ text. Layer: precision

entries.title: Spacing token: tight (8px)
entries.description: Use: Label ↔ input. Layer: both

entries.title: Spacing token: compact (12px)
entries.description: Use: Button groups, tight lists. Layer: precision

entries.title: Spacing token: base (16px)
entries.description: Use: Within component. Layer: both

entries.title: Spacing token: related (20px)
entries.description: Use: Related content groups. Layer: precision

entries.title: Spacing token: comfortable (24px)
entries.description: Use: Between components. Layer: both

entries.description: Use: Between sections. Layer: rhythm

entries.description: Use: Major sections. Layer: rhythm

entries.title: Layout anti-pattern: fillingEveryGap
entries.description: Filling every available gap with content reduces scannability, makes layouts harder to parse, and forces users to work harder to understand structure
entries.why: If everything is filled, nothing stands out
entries.counterExample: Use white space to define grouping, separate content blocks, and clarify intent — leave intentional gaps

entries.title: Layout anti-pattern: sectionsBleeding
entries.description: Sections visually bleed into each other when vertical gaps between sections are not significantly larger than gaps within sections
entries.why: Spacing is the primary signal of hierarchy
entries.counterExample: Use section-level tokens (gap-12/gap-16, 48-64px) between sections and smaller tokens (gap-4/gap-6, 16-24px) within sections — the ratio should be at least 2:1

entries.title: Layout anti-pattern: crowdingTextBlocks
entries.description: Tight paragraphs and minimal line/section spacing kills readability and increases cognitive load, making long-form content exhausting to read
entries.why: Readability depends more on space than on font choice
entries.counterExample: Increase spacing between paragraphs more than between lines — use mb-4 to mb-6 between paragraphs, leading-relaxed for long-form content

entries.title: Layout anti-pattern: overpackingComponents
entries.description: Stuffing cards and components with too many elements (buttons, tags, metadata, badges) increases cognitive load and blurs the component's primary purpose
entries.why: More content does not equal more value — one clear intent per component
entries.counterExample: Remove non-essential elements, use progressive disclosure (expand/detail views), limit cards to: title + description + 1 primary action + 1-2 metadata items

entries.title: Layout anti-pattern: inconsistentComponentSpacing
entries.description: Each component inventing its own internal spacing logic makes the system feel fragmented and harder to maintain at scale
entries.why: Components inherit spacing rules from the system — spacing tokens are reused, not improvised
entries.counterExample: Define spacing tokens per component type: cards use p-6, forms use space-y-4, button groups use gap-2 or gap-3 — never ad-hoc values

entries.title: Layout anti-pattern: ignoringVerticalRhythm
entries.description: Treating spacing as purely horizontal while ignoring vertical rhythm makes the interface flow feel erratic and uncomfortable
entries.why: Vertical spacing controls pace, comfort, and flow
entries.counterExample: Establish predictable Y-axis spacing patterns — repeat the same vertical rhythm across sections using the 8pt rhythm layer

entries.title: Spacing principle: Space defines grouping and separates content blocks
entries.description: Space defines grouping and separates content blocks
entries.context: White space is not empty — it is an active design tool that creates structure, hierarchy, focus, rhythm, and comfort. Treating space as 'unused' leads to clutter, cognitive overload, and loss of hierarchy.

entries.title: Nested border radius: Outer = Inner + Padding
entries.description: Outer = Inner + Padding. inner xs (4) + padding xs (4) = outer sm (8); inner sm (8) + padding xs (4) = outer md (12); inner sm (8) + padding sm (8) = outer lg (16); inner md (12) + padding sm (8) = outer xl (20)
